items.title: What if you made the ant bigger instead?
items.content:
You'd design: Longer context windows, better memory, one super-agent.
Why this fails: Context still degrades at 80K tokens. Single point of failure. No parallelism.
Hidden constraint: Transformer physics limits single-agent approaches. Colony beats ant.

items.title: The irreducible core
items.content:
gt mayor attach
Essential: You technically only need the Mayor.
Everything else: Refinement for scale, reliability, and parallelism.

items.title: Steve Yegge: ~225K lines of vibe-coded Go
items.content: Gas Town + Beads combined. 11K+ GitHub stars on Beads. "I never read the code myself." 100% AI-generated factory-scale software.

items.title: Gas Town = Restaurant Kitchen
items.content:
Restaurant Owner -> Overseer (YOU)
Head Chef -> Mayor
Line Cooks -> Polecats
Ticket System -> Beads
Expediter -> Witness

If you've managed a kitchen, you understand Gas Town.

items.title: One insight -> FIVE architecture decisions
items.content:
ROOT: "Nature prefers colonies"
-> Agents are workers, not assistants
-> You're PM, not programmer
-> Specialization per role
-> Parallel execution native
-> Persistent memory required (Beads)

items.title: INV-003: External state > internal memory
items.content: Gas Town, Ralph, CC Mirror all share this invariant. Beads IS external state for Gas Town. Without it, agents wake up with "50 First Dates" syndrome.

items.title: How deep is your understanding?
items.content:
Beginner: "What are the 8 roles?" -> Listed in hierarchy
Intermediate: "Why Opus for Mayor?" -> Coordination needs top reasoning
Advanced: "Why Haiku for Witness?" -> Observation is cheap
Staff: "When skip roles?" -> Mayor-only for tutorials
Expert: "How compose with Ralph?" -> Polecat runs internal Ralph loop

items.title: The Model Selection Dilemma
items.content:
Opus everywhere: Best quality, but $200+/day
Sonnet everywhere: Affordable, but coordination suffers
Mixed (Gas Town): Balanced, but complexity managing models

Heuristic: Opus for coordination, Sonnet for implementation, Haiku for observation.

items.title: If you skip the Refinery
items.content:
IF: Polecats push directly to main
THEN: Multiple agents edit same files
THEN: Merge conflicts compound
THEN: Agents "savagely overwrite each other"
FINALLY: Codebase corrupted, work lost

The fix: ALL work flows through Refinery. No exceptions.

items.title: Gas Town = Traditional Software Company
items.content:
CEO -> Overseer (YOU)
COO -> Mayor
IT/DevOps -> Deacon
QA Team -> Dogs
Tech Lead -> Refinery
Team Lead -> Witness
Sr. Developers -> Polecats
Staff Engineer -> Crew

You're not learning new concepts. You're automating familiar org structure.

items.title: Gas Town + Ralph
items.content:
Works: Polecat runs internal Ralph loop for focused feature work.
Pattern: Create Beads issue with PRD -> Sling to polecat -> Polecat runs Ralph -> Refinery merges result.
When: Well-defined feature with clear acceptance criteria.

items.title: When polecats flip from help to hurt
items.content:
3-5 polecats: Linear productivity increase
5-10 polecats: Coordination overhead appears
10-20 polecats: Refinery becomes bottleneck
20+ polecats: Merge conflicts dominate

THE INFLECTION: ~10 polecats per rig
Detection: If Refinery queue is always full, you have too many polecats.

items.title: How productivity perception evolves
items.content:
Day 1: "This setup is overwhelming"
Week 1: "I'm still fixing bugs from yesterday"
Week 2: "Wait, I shipped 5 features while I slept"
Month 1: "This is 10x my previous output"

Don't judge Gas Town by Day 1.

items.title: How Gas Town fails gradually
items.content:
100% -> 90%: Occasional stuck polecat (Witness fixes)
90% -> 70%: Refinery queue backing up (too many polecats)
70% -> 50%: Merge conflicts piling up (Refinery overwhelmed)
50% -> CLIFF: Agents overwriting each other (200K LOC wall)

Critical: Monitor Refinery queue. That's your early warning.

items.title: At 200K+ LOC, the merge wall appears
items.content:
What happens: Too many files, too many changes, agents start conflicting constantly.
Threshold: ~200K lines of code
Mitigation: Split into multiple rigs by domain. Frontend rig, Backend rig, Infra rig.

items.title: What if Deacon was stable?
items.content:
You'd have: Automatic patrol, recycling, heartbeat.
Why it's unstable: Complex state management across many agents.
Workaround: Run without Deacon. Manual supervision until v0.4.0.

items.title: UNSOLVED: Optimal polecat scaling
items.content:
The question: How many polecats per rig? Per codebase size? Per task complexity?
Why hard: Depends on codebase structure, file overlap, task granularity.
Current best: Start with 3, add more if Refinery queue is empty.

items.title: If you ignore Beads sync
items.content:
IF: You skip bd sync
THEN: Agents have stale task state
THEN: Same task assigned to multiple polecats
THEN: Duplicate work, wasted cost
FINALLY: Conflicting implementations compete

The fix: Beads sync runs automatically. If it fails, fix before continuing.

items.title: Throughput vs. Control
items.content:
THE DILEMMA:
- Full control: You review every commit -> slow, but safe
- Full autonomy: Factory runs overnight -> fast, but risky
- Hybrid: Review major decisions -> balanced, but judgment required

WHY NO PERFECT ANSWER: Your risk tolerance is personal.
Heuristic: Start with more control, reduce as you build trust.

items.title: Yegge: "Superintelligent chimpanzees"
items.content: "If you're not at Stage 7, you'll get your face ripped off by superintelligent chimpanzees." The agents are powerful but chaotic. Expect the unexpected.

items.title: Stage Requirements Understanding
items.content:
Stage 4: "What's the prerequisite?" -> 100+ hours multi-agent
Stage 5: "Can I skip Ralph?" -> No, the experience is essential
Stage 6: "How do I know I'm ready?" -> You've shipped 5+ overnight features
Stage 7: "What's the evolution?" -> Ralph -> CC Mirror -> Worktrees -> Gas Town
Expert: "What comes after Gas Town?" -> Nothing yet. This is the frontier.

items.title: If Gas Town isn't right for you
items.content:
New to orchestration? -> Ralph (Level 4)
Cost-sensitive? -> CC Mirror (Level 5)
Need parallelism but simpler? -> Worktrees (Level 6)
Prefer hub-and-spoke? -> Orchestra
Single focused task? -> Single Claude session

items.title: Gas Town + Roughneck
items.content:
Works: Multiple Gas Town factories on cloud VMs.
Pattern: Roughneck provisions Hetzner/AWS/DO with Gas Town pre-installed.
Use case: Multi-cloud, geographic distribution, cost optimization by tier.

items.title: The "Before/After" transformation
items.content:
BEFORE: You write code, Claude assists, 8 hours coding, 1 feature, sleep
AFTER: You define features, polecats implement, 30 min planning, 10 features, factory works overnight

This is the mindset shift. You become PM, not programmer.

items.title: Gas Town, Ralph, CC Mirror share core DNA
items.content:
All three patterns implement:
- External state > internal memory
- Fresh context beats extended sessions
- Verification gates required

Understanding one helps you understand all.

items.title: At 50+ agent-hours, patterns emerge
items.content:
What happens: You start recognizing which task types suit which roles. Mayor for decomposition, Polecats for implementation, Crew for exploration.
Implication: Your task assignment becomes intuitive, not checklist-driven.

items.title: UNSOLVED: Dynamic role scaling
items.content:
The question: Should roles scale up/down based on workload? Can Deacon spawn polecats automatically?
Why hard: Cost control vs. throughput optimization. No automation yet.
Current: Manual polecat management via gt config set max_polecats.

items.title: Community: GTGUI Age of Empires interface
items.content: @TRIBE-INC building GUI for Gas Town with Age of Empires-style minimap showing agent locations and status. Not production-ready, but shows the community investment in making Gas Town more accessible.

items.title: How trust degrades in Gas Town
items.content:
100% -> 90%: First bug in agent-written code (expected)
90% -> 70%: Unexpected merge conflict (Refinery handles)
70% -> 50%: Feature shipped broken (tests didn't catch it)
50% -> CLIFF: Overnight run produces garbage (configuration issue)

Critical: Build trust gradually. Start with Mayor-only.

items.title: Budget constraint -> FIVE operational decisions
items.content:
ROOT: $50-200/day budget constraint
-> Use Haiku for Witness (observation)
-> Limit polecats to 5-10
-> Batch overnight runs
-> Monitor API dashboard daily
-> Kill unnecessary Crew members

items.title: Minimal viable Gas Town
items.content:
gt mayor attach
+ gt polecat up myproject alice
+ bd init

Essential: Mayor, one polecat, Beads.
Everything else: Scaling refinements.

items.title: When Mayor becomes essential
items.content:
1-3 polecats: You can direct-assign via gt sling
3-5 polecats: Mayor helps but not essential
5-10 polecats: Mayor coordination becomes necessary
10+ polecats: Mayor is critical for work distribution

THE INFLECTION: ~5 polecats
Below 5: Mayor optional. Above 5: Mayor required.

items.title: What if you had perfect cost visibility?
items.content:
You'd have: Real-time spending dashboard, automatic budget caps, alerts.
Why missing: Gas Town is orchestration, not billing. API providers own cost data.
Workaround: Check Anthropic dashboard daily. Set max limits in config.

items.title: Gas Town = Idea Compiler
items.content:
Input: Your ideas and feature requests
Compilation: Mayor decomposes, Beads tracks, Polecats implement
Output: Working code, shipped products

"You just make up features, design them, file the implementation plans, and sling work around."

items.title: How Beads perception evolves
items.content:
Day 1: "Another issue tracker?"
Week 1: "Oh, agents can query this"
Week 2: "This IS the agent memory"
Month 1: "Without Beads, none of this works"

Beads isn't overhead. Beads is the substrate.
